text: God, after He spoke long ago to the fathers in the prophets in many portions and in many ways,
speaker: Narrator

text: in these last days has spoken to us in His Son, whom He appointed heir of all things, through whom He also made the world.
speaker: Narrator

text: And He is the radiance of His glory and the exact representation of His nature, and upholds all things by the word of His power. When He had made purification of sins, He sat down at the right hand of the Majesty on high,
speaker: Narrator

text: having become so much better than the angels, to the extent that He has inherited a more excellent name than they.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For to which of the angels did He ever say,
“You are My Son,
Today I have fathered You”?
And again,
“I will be a Father to Him
And He will be a Son to Me”?
speaker: Narrator

text:
And when He again brings the firstborn into the world, He says,
“And let all the angels of God worship Him.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
And regarding the angels He says,
“He makes His angels winds,
And His ministers a flame of fire.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
But regarding the Son He says,
“Your throne, God, is forever and ever,
And the scepter of righteousness is the scepter of His kingdom.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
They will perish, but You remain;
And they all will wear out like a garment,
speaker: Narrator

text:
And like a robe You will roll them up;
Like a garment they will also be changed.
But You are the same,
And Your years will not come to an end.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
But to which of the angels has He ever said,
“Sit at My right hand,
Until I make Your enemies
A footstool for Your feet”?
speaker: Narrator

text: Are they not all ministering spirits, sent out to provide service for the sake of those who will inherit salvation?
speaker: Narrator

text: For this reason we must pay much closer attention to what we have heard, so that we do not drift away from it.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if the word spoken through angels proved unalterable, and every violation and act of disobedience received a just punishment,
speaker: Narrator

text: how will we escape if we neglect so great a salvation? After it was at first spoken through the Lord, it was confirmed to us by those who heard,
speaker: Narrator

text: God also testifying with them, both by signs and wonders, and by various miracles and by gifts of the Holy Spirit according to His own will.
speaker: Narrator

text: For He did not subject to angels the world to come, about which we are speaking.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But someone has testified somewhere, saying,
“What is man, that You think of him?
Or a son of man, that You are concerned about him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have made him for a little while lower than angels;
You have crowned him with glory and honor;
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have put everything in subjection under his feet.”
For in subjecting all things to him, He left nothing that is not subject to him. But now we do not yet see all things subjected to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But we do see Him who was made for a little while lower than the angels, namely, Jesus, because of His suffering death crowned with glory and honor, so that by the grace of God He might taste death for everyone.
speaker: Narrator

text: For it was fitting for Him, for whom are all things, and through whom are all things, in bringing many sons to glory, to perfect the originator of their salvation through sufferings.
speaker: Narrator

text: For both He who sanctifies and those who are sanctified are all from one Father; for this reason He is not ashamed to call them brothers and sisters,
speaker: Narrator

text:
saying,
“I will proclaim Your name to My brothers,
In the midst of the assembly I will sing Your praise.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
And again,
“I will put My trust in Him.”
And again,
“Behold, I and the children whom God has given Me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, since the children share in flesh and blood, He Himself likewise also partook of the same, so that through death He might destroy the one who has the power of death, that is, the devil,
speaker: Narrator

text: and free those who through fear of death were subject to slavery all their lives.
speaker: Narrator

text: For clearly He does not give help to angels, but He gives help to the descendants of Abraham.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, in all things He had to be made like His brothers so that He might become a merciful and faithful high priest in things pertaining to God, to make propitiation for the sins of the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: For since He Himself was tempted in that which He has suffered, He is able to come to the aid of those who are tempted.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, holy brothers and sisters, partakers of a heavenly calling, consider the Apostle and High Priest of our confession: Jesus;
speaker: Narrator

text: He was faithful to Him who appointed Him, as Moses also was in all His house.
speaker: Narrator

text: For He has been counted worthy of more glory than Moses, by just so much as the builder of the house has more honor than the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: For every house is built by someone, but the builder of all things is God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Moses was faithful in all God’s house as a servant, for a testimony of those things which were to be spoken later;
speaker: Narrator

text: but Christ was faithful as a Son over His house—whose house we are, if we hold firmly to our confidence and the boast of our hope.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore, just as the Holy Spirit says,
“Today if you hear His voice,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not harden your hearts as when they provoked Me,
As on the day of trial in the wilderness,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Where your fathers put Me to the test,
And saw My works for forty years.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
As I swore in My anger,
‘They certainly shall not enter My rest.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Take care, brothers and sisters, that there will not be in any one of you an evil, unbelieving heart that falls away from the living God.
speaker: Narrator

text: But encourage one another every day, as long as it is still called “today,” so that none of you will be hardened by the deceitfulness of sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: For we have become partakers of Christ if we keep the beginning of our commitment firm until the end,
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: For who provoked Him when they had heard? Indeed, did not all those who came out of Egypt led by Moses?
speaker: Narrator

text: And with whom was He angry for forty years? Was it not with those who sinned, whose dead bodies fell in the wilderness?
speaker: Narrator

text: And to whom did He swear that they would not enter His rest, but to those who were disobedient?
speaker: Narrator

text: And so we see that they were not able to enter because of unbelief.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, we must fear if, while a promise remains of entering His rest, any one of you may seem to have come short of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: For indeed we have had good news preached to us, just as they also did; but the word they heard did not benefit them, because they were not united with those who listened with faith.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For we who have believed enter that rest, just as He has said,
“As I swore in My anger,
They certainly shall not enter My rest,”
although His works were finished from the foundation of the world.
speaker: Narrator

text: For He has said somewhere concerning the seventh day: “And God rested on the seventh day from all His works”;
speaker: Narrator

text: and again in this passage, “They certainly shall not enter My rest.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, since it remains for some to enter it, and those who previously had good news preached to them failed to enter because of disobedience,
speaker: Narrator

text:
He again sets a certain day, “Today,” saying through David after so long a time just as has been said before,
“Today if you hear His voice,
Do not harden your hearts.”
speaker: Narrator

text: For if Joshua had given them rest, He would not have spoken of another day after that.
speaker: Narrator

text: Consequently, there remains a Sabbath rest for the people of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the one who has entered His rest has himself also rested from his works, as God did from His.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore let’s make every effort to enter that rest, so that no one will fall by following the same example of disobedience.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the word of God is living and active, and sharper than any two-edged sword, even penetrating as far as the division of soul and spirit, of both joints and marrow, and able to judge the thoughts and intentions of the heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: And there is no creature hidden from His sight, but all things are open and laid bare to the eyes of Him to whom we must answer.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, since we have a great high priest who has passed through the heavens, Jesus the Son of God, let’s hold firmly to our confession.
speaker: Narrator

text: For we do not have a high priest who cannot sympathize with our weaknesses, but One who has been tempted in all things just as we are, yet without sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore let’s approach the throne of grace with confidence, so that we may receive mercy and find grace for help at the time of our need.
speaker: Narrator

text: For every high priest taken from among men is appointed on behalf of people in things pertaining to God, in order to offer both gifts and sacrifices for sins;
speaker: Narrator

text: he can deal gently with the ignorant and misguided, since he himself also is clothed in weakness;
speaker: Narrator

text: and because of it he is obligated to offer sacrifices for sins for himself, as well as for the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: And no one takes the honor for himself, but receives it when he is called by God, just as Aaron also was.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
just as He also says in another passage,
“You are a priest forever
According to the order of Melchizedek.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In the days of His humanity, He offered up both prayers and pleas with loud crying and tears to the One able to save Him from death, and He was heard because of His devout behavior.
speaker: Narrator

text: Although He was a Son, He learned obedience from the things which He suffered.
speaker: Narrator

text: And having been perfected, He became the source of eternal salvation for all those who obey Him,
speaker: Narrator

text: being designated by God as High Priest according to the order of Melchizedek.
speaker: Narrator

text: Concerning him we have much to say, and it is difficult to explain, since you have become poor listeners.
speaker: Narrator

text: For though by this time you ought to be teachers, you have need again for someone to teach you the elementary principles of the actual words of God, and you have come to need milk and not solid food.
speaker: Narrator

text: For everyone who partakes only of milk is unacquainted with the word of righteousness, for he is an infant.
speaker: Narrator

text: But solid food is for the mature, who because of practice have their senses trained to distinguish between good and evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore leaving the elementary teaching about the Christ, let us press on to maturity, not laying again a foundation of repentance from dead works and of faith toward God,
speaker: Narrator

text: of instruction about washings and laying on of hands, and about the resurrection of the dead and eternal judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text: And this we will do, if God permits.
speaker: Narrator

text: For it is impossible, in the case of those who have once been enlightened and have tasted of the heavenly gift and have been made partakers of the Holy Spirit,
speaker: Narrator

text: and have tasted the good word of God and the powers of the age to come,
speaker: Narrator

text: and then have fallen away, to restore them again to repentance, since they again crucify to themselves the Son of God and put Him to open shame.
speaker: Narrator

text: For ground that drinks the rain which often falls on it and produces vegetation useful to those for whose sake it is also tilled, receives a blessing from God;
speaker: Narrator

text: but if it yields thorns and thistles, it is worthless and close to being cursed, and it ends up being burned.
speaker: Narrator

text: But, beloved, we are convinced of better things regarding you, and things that accompany salvation, even though we are speaking in this way.
speaker: Narrator

text: For God is not unjust so as to forget your work and the love which you have shown toward His name, by having served and by still serving the saints.
speaker: Narrator

text: And we desire that each one of you demonstrate the same diligence so as to realize the full assurance of hope until the end,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that you will not be sluggish, but imitators of those who through faith and endurance inherit the promises.
speaker: Narrator

text: For when God made the promise to Abraham, since He could swear an oath by no one greater, He swore by Himself,
speaker: Narrator

text: saying, “indeed I will greatly bless you and I will greatly multiply you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And so, having patiently waited, he obtained the promise.
speaker: Narrator

text: For people swear an oath by one greater than themselves, and with them an oath serving as confirmation is an end of every dispute.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the same way God, desiring even more to demonstrate to the heirs of the promise the fact that His purpose is unchangeable, confirmed it with an oath,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that by two unchangeable things in which it is impossible for God to lie, we who have taken refuge would have strong encouragement to hold firmly to the hope set before us.
speaker: Narrator

text: This hope we have as an anchor of the soul, a hope both sure and reliable and one which enters within the veil,
speaker: Narrator

text: where Jesus has entered as a forerunner for us, having become a high priest forever according to the order of Melchizedek.
speaker: Narrator

text: For this Melchizedek, king of Salem, priest of the Most High God, who met Abraham as he was returning from the slaughter of the kings and blessed him,
speaker: Narrator

text: to whom also Abraham apportioned a tenth of all the spoils, was first of all, by the translation of his name, king of righteousness, and then also king of Salem, which is king of peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: Without father, without mother, without genealogy, having neither beginning of days nor end of life, but made like the Son of God, he remains a priest perpetually.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now observe how great this man was to whom Abraham, the patriarch, gave a tenth of the choicest spoils.
speaker: Narrator

text: And those indeed of the sons of Levi who receive the priest’s office have a commandment in the Law to collect a tenth from the people, that is, from their countrymen, although they are descended from Abraham.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the one whose genealogy is not traced from them collected a tenth from Abraham and blessed the one who had the promises.
speaker: Narrator

text: But without any dispute the lesser person is blessed by the greater.
speaker: Narrator

text: In this case mortal men receive tithes, but in that case one receives them, of whom it is witnessed that he lives on.
speaker: Narrator

text: And, so to speak, through Abraham even Levi, who received tithes, has paid tithes,
speaker: Narrator

text: for he was still in the loins of his forefather when Melchizedek met him.
speaker: Narrator

text: So if perfection was through the Levitical priesthood (for on the basis of it the people received the Law), what further need was there for another priest to arise according to the order of Melchizedek, and not be designated according to the order of Aaron?
speaker: Narrator

text: For when the priesthood is changed, of necessity there takes place a change of law also.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the one about whom these things are said belongs to another tribe, from which no one has officiated at the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: For it is evident that our Lord was descended from Judah, a tribe with reference to which Moses said nothing concerning priests.
speaker: Narrator

text: And this is clearer still, if another priest arises according to the likeness of Melchizedek,
speaker: Narrator

text: who has become a priest not on the basis of a law of physical requirement, but according to the power of an indestructible life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For it is attested of Him,
“You are a priest forever
According to the order of Melchizedek.”
speaker: Narrator

text: For, on the one hand, there is the nullification of a former commandment because of its weakness and uselessness
speaker: Narrator

text: (for the Law made nothing perfect); on the other hand, there is the introduction of a better hope, through which we come near to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: And to the extent that it was not without an oath
speaker: Narrator

text:
(for they indeed became priests without an oath, but He with an oath through the One who said to Him,
“The Lord has sworn
And will not change His mind,
‘You are a priest forever’”);
speaker: Narrator

text: by the same extent Jesus also has become the guarantee of a better covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: The former priests, on the one hand, existed in greater numbers because they were prevented by death from continuing;
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus, on the other hand, because He continues forever, holds His priesthood permanently.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore He is also able to save forever those who come to God through Him, since He always lives to make intercession for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: For it was fitting for us to have such a high priest, holy, innocent, undefiled, separated from sinners, and exalted above the heavens;
speaker: Narrator

text: who has no daily need, like those high priests, to offer up sacrifices, first for His own sins and then for the sins of the people, because He did this once for all time when He offered up Himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Law appoints men as high priests who are weak, but the word of the oath, which came after the Law, appoints a Son, who has been made perfect forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the main point in what has been said is this: we have such a high priest, who has taken His seat at the right hand of the throne of the Majesty in the heavens,
speaker: Narrator

text: a minister in the sanctuary and in the true tabernacle, which the Lord set up, not man.
speaker: Narrator

text: For every high priest is appointed to offer both gifts and sacrifices; so it is necessary that this high priest also have something to offer.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now if He were on earth, He would not be a priest at all, since there are those who offer the gifts according to the Law;
speaker: Narrator

text: who serve a copy and shadow of the heavenly things, just as Moses was warned by God when he was about to erect the tabernacle; for, “See,” He says, “that you make all things by the pattern which was shown to you on the mountain.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But now He has obtained a more excellent ministry, to the extent that He is also the mediator of a better covenant, which has been enacted on better promises.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if that first covenant had been free of fault, no circumstances would have been sought for a second.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For in finding fault with the people, He says,
“Behold, days are coming, says the Lord,
When I will bring about a new covenant
With the house of Israel and the house of Judah,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Not like the covenant which I made with their fathers
On the day I took them by the hand
To bring them out of the land of Egypt;
For they did not continue in My covenant,
And I did not care about them, says the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For this is the covenant which I will make with the house of Israel
After those days, declares the Lord:
I will put My laws into their minds,
And write them on their hearts.
And I will be their God,
And they shall be My people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And they will not teach, each one his fellow citizen,
And each one his brother, saying, ‘Know the Lord,’
For they will all know Me,
From the least to the greatest of them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For I will be merciful toward their wrongdoings,
And their sins I will no longer remember.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When He said, “A new covenant,” He has made the first obsolete. But whatever is becoming obsolete and growing old is about to disappear.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now even the first covenant had regulations for divine worship and the earthly sanctuary.
speaker: Narrator

text: For a tabernacle was equipped, the outer sanctuary, in which were the lampstand, the table, and the sacred bread; this is called the Holy Place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Behind the second veil there was a tabernacle which is called the Most Holy Place,
speaker: Narrator

text: having a golden altar of incense and the ark of the covenant covered on all sides with gold, in which was a golden jar holding the manna, Aaron’s staff which budded, and the tablets of the covenant;
speaker: Narrator

text: and above it were the cherubim of glory overshadowing the atoning cover; but about these things we cannot now speak in detail.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now when these things have been so prepared, the priests are continually entering the outer tabernacle, performing the divine worship,
speaker: Narrator

text: but into the second, only the high priest enters once a year, not without taking blood which he offers for himself and for the sins of the people committed in ignorance.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Holy Spirit is signifying this, that the way into the holy place has not yet been disclosed while the outer tabernacle is still standing,
speaker: Narrator

text: which is a symbol for the present time. Accordingly both gifts and sacrifices are offered which cannot make the worshiper perfect in conscience,
speaker: Narrator

text: since they relate only to food, drink, and various washings, regulations for the body imposed until a time of reformation.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when Christ appeared as a high priest of the good things having come, He entered through the greater and more perfect tabernacle, not made by hands, that is, not of this creation;
speaker: Narrator

text: and not through the blood of goats and calves, but through His own blood, He entered the holy place once for all time, having obtained eternal redemption.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if the blood of goats and bulls, and the ashes of a heifer sprinkling those who have been defiled, sanctify for the cleansing of the flesh,
speaker: Narrator

text: how much more will the blood of Christ, who through the eternal Spirit offered Himself without blemish to God, cleanse your conscience from dead works to serve the living God?
speaker: Narrator

text: For this reason He is the mediator of a new covenant, so that, since a death has taken place for the redemption of the violations that were committed under the first covenant, those who have been called may receive the promise of the eternal inheritance.
speaker: Narrator

text: For where there is a covenant, there must of necessity be the death of the one who made it.
speaker: Narrator

text: For a covenant is valid only when people are dead, for it is never in force while the one who made it lives.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore even the first covenant was not inaugurated without blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: For when every commandment had been spoken by Moses to all the people according to the Law, he took the blood of the calves and the goats, with water and scarlet wool and hyssop, and sprinkled both the book itself and all the people,
speaker: Narrator

text: saying, “This is the blood of the covenant which God commanded you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And in the same way he sprinkled both the tabernacle and all the vessels of the ministry with the blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: And almost all things are cleansed with blood, according to the Law, and without the shedding of blood there is no forgiveness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore it was necessary for the copies of the things in the heavens to be cleansed with these things, but the heavenly things themselves with better sacrifices than these.
speaker: Narrator

text: For Christ did not enter a holy place made by hands, a mere copy of the true one, but into heaven itself, now to appear in the presence of God for us;
speaker: Narrator

text: nor was it that He would offer Himself often, as the high priest enters the Holy Place year by year with blood that is not his own.
speaker: Narrator

text: Otherwise, He would have needed to suffer often since the foundation of the world; but now once at the consummation of the ages He has been revealed to put away sin by the sacrifice of Himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: And just as it is destined for people to die once, and after this comes judgment,
speaker: Narrator

text: so Christ also, having been offered once to bear the sins of many, will appear a second time for salvation without reference to sin, to those who eagerly await Him.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Law, since it has only a shadow of the good things to come and not the form of those things itself, can never, by the same sacrifices which they offer continually every year, make those who approach perfect.
speaker: Narrator

text: Otherwise, would they not have ceased to be offered, because the worshipers, having once been cleansed, would no longer have had consciousness of sins?
speaker: Narrator

text: But in those sacrifices there is a reminder of sins every year.
speaker: Narrator

text: For it is impossible for the blood of bulls and goats to take away sins.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: You have not taken pleasure in whole burnt offerings and offerings for sin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then I said, ‘Behold, I have come
(It is written of Me in the scroll of the book)
To do Your will, O God.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: After saying above, “Sacrifices and offerings and whole burnt offerings and offerings for sin You have not desired, nor have You taken pleasure in them” (which are offered according to the Law),
speaker: Narrator

text: then He said, “Behold, I have come to do Your will.” He takes away the first in order to establish the second.
speaker: Narrator

text: By this will, we have been sanctified through the offering of the body of Jesus Christ once for all time.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every priest stands daily ministering and offering time after time the same sacrifices, which can never take away sins;
speaker: Narrator

text: but He, having offered one sacrifice for sins for all time, sat down at the right hand of God,
speaker: Narrator

text: waiting from that time onward until His enemies are made a footstool for His feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: For by one offering He has perfected for all time those who are sanctified.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Holy Spirit also testifies to us; for after saying,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“This is the covenant which I will make with them
After those days, declares the Lord:
I will put My laws upon their hearts,
And write them on their mind,”
He then says,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“And their sins and their lawless deeds
I will no longer remember.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now where there is forgiveness of these things, an offering for sin is no longer required.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, brothers and sisters, since we have confidence to enter the holy place by the blood of Jesus,
speaker: Narrator

text: by a new and living way which He inaugurated for us through the veil, that is, through His flesh,
speaker: Narrator

text: and since we have a great priest over the house of God,
speaker: Narrator

text: let’s approach God with a sincere heart in full assurance of faith, having our hearts sprinkled clean from an evil conscience and our bodies washed with pure water.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let’s hold firmly to the confession of our hope without wavering, for He who promised is faithful;
speaker: Narrator

text: and let’s consider how to encourage one another in love and good deeds,
speaker: Narrator

text: not abandoning our own meeting together, as is the habit of some people, but encouraging one another; and all the more as you see the day drawing near.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if we go on sinning willfully after receiving the knowledge of the truth, there no longer remains a sacrifice for sins,
speaker: Narrator

text: but a terrifying expectation of judgment and the fury of a fire which will consume the adversaries.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who has ignored the Law of Moses is put to death without mercy on the testimony of two or three witnesses.
speaker: Narrator

text: How much more severe punishment do you think he will deserve who has trampled underfoot the Son of God, and has regarded as unclean the blood of the covenant by which he was sanctified, and has insulted the Spirit of grace?
speaker: Narrator

text: For we know Him who said, “Vengeance is Mine, I will repay.” And again, “The Lord will judge His people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: It is a terrifying thing to fall into the hands of the living God.
speaker: Narrator

text: But remember the former days, when, after being enlightened, you endured a great conflict of sufferings,
speaker: Narrator

text: partly by being made a public spectacle through insults and distress, and partly by becoming companions with those who were so treated.
speaker: Narrator

text: For you showed sympathy to the prisoners and accepted joyfully the seizure of your property, knowing that you have for yourselves a better and lasting possession.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, do not throw away your confidence, which has a great reward.
speaker: Narrator

text: For you have need of endurance, so that when you have done the will of God, you may receive what was promised.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For yet in a very little while,
He who is coming will come, and will not delay.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But My righteous one will live by faith;
And if he shrinks back, My soul has no pleasure in him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But we are not among those who shrink back to destruction, but of those who have faith for the safekeeping of the soul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now faith is the certainty of things hoped for, a proof of things not seen.
speaker: Narrator

text: For by it the people of old gained approval.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith we understand that the world has been created by the word of God so that what is seen has not been made out of things that are visible.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith Abel offered to God a better sacrifice than Cain, through which he was attested to be righteous, God testifying about his gifts, and through faith, though he is dead, he still speaks.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith Enoch was taken up so that he would not see death; and he was not found because God took him up; for before he was taken up, he was attested to have been pleasing to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: And without faith it is impossible to please Him, for the one who comes to God must believe that He exists, and that He proves to be One who rewards those who seek Him.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith Noah, being warned by God about things not yet seen, in reverence prepared an ark for the salvation of his household, by which he condemned the world, and became an heir of the righteousness which is according to faith.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith Abraham, when he was called, obeyed by going out to a place which he was to receive for an inheritance; and he left, not knowing where he was going.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith he lived as a stranger in the land of promise, as in a foreign land, living in tents with Isaac and Jacob, fellow heirs of the same promise;
speaker: Narrator

text: for he was looking for the city which has foundations, whose architect and builder is God.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith even Sarah herself received ability to conceive, even beyond the proper time of life, since she considered Him faithful who had promised.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore even from one man, and one who was as good as dead at that, there were born descendants who were just as the stars of heaven in number, and as the innumerable grains of sand along the seashore.
speaker: Narrator

text: All these died in faith, without receiving the promises, but having seen and welcomed them from a distance, and having confessed that they were strangers and exiles on the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: For those who say such things make it clear that they are seeking a country of their own.
speaker: Narrator

text: And indeed if they had been thinking of that country which they left, they would have had opportunity to return.
speaker: Narrator

text: But as it is, they desire a better country, that is, a heavenly one. Therefore God is not ashamed to be called their God; for He has prepared a city for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith Abraham, when he was tested, offered up Isaac, and the one who had received the promises was offering up his only son;
speaker: Narrator

text: it was he to whom it was said, “Through Isaac your descendants shall be named.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He considered that God is able to raise people even from the dead, from which he also received him back as a type.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith Isaac blessed Jacob and Esau, even regarding things to come.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith Jacob, as he was dying, blessed each of the sons of Joseph, and worshiped, leaning on the top of his staff.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith Joseph, when he was dying, made mention of the exodus of the sons of Israel, and gave orders concerning his bones.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith Moses, when he was born, was hidden for three months by his parents, because they saw he was a beautiful child; and they were not afraid of the king’s edict.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith Moses, when he had grown up, refused to be called the son of Pharaoh’s daughter,
speaker: Narrator

text: choosing rather to endure ill-treatment with the people of God than to enjoy the temporary pleasures of sin,
speaker: Narrator

text: considering the reproach of Christ greater riches than the treasures of Egypt; for he was looking to the reward.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith he left Egypt, not fearing the wrath of the king; for he persevered, as though seeing Him who is unseen.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith he kept the Passover and the sprinkling of the blood, so that the destroyer of the firstborn would not touch them.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith they passed through the Red Sea as through dry land; and the Egyptians, when they attempted it, were drowned.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith the walls of Jericho fell down after the Israelites had marched around them for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith the prostitute Rahab did not perish along with those who were disobedient, after she had welcomed the spies in peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: And what more shall I say? For time will fail me if I tell of Gideon, Barak, Samson, Jephthah, of David and Samuel and the prophets,
speaker: Narrator

text: who by faith conquered kingdoms, performed acts of righteousness, obtained promises, shut the mouths of lions,
speaker: Narrator

text: quenched the power of fire, escaped the edge of the sword, from weakness were made strong, became mighty in war, put foreign armies to flight.
speaker: Narrator

text: Women received back their dead by resurrection; and others were tortured, not accepting their release, so that they might obtain a better resurrection;
speaker: Narrator

text: and others experienced mocking and flogging, and further, chains and imprisonment.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were stoned, they were sawn in two, they were tempted, they were put to death with the sword; they went about in sheepskins, in goatskins, being destitute, afflicted, tormented
speaker: Narrator

text: (people of whom the world was not worthy), wandering in deserts, on mountains, and sheltering in caves and holes in the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: And all these, having gained approval through their faith, did not receive what was promised,
speaker: Narrator

text: because God had provided something better for us, so that apart from us they would not be made perfect.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, since we also have such a great cloud of witnesses surrounding us, let’s rid ourselves of every obstacle and the sin which so easily entangles us, and let’s run with endurance the race that is set before us,
speaker: Narrator

text: looking only at Jesus, the originator and perfecter of the faith, who for the joy set before Him endured the cross, despising the shame, and has sat down at the right hand of the throne of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For consider Him who has endured such hostility by sinners against Himself, so that you will not grow weary and lose heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have not yet resisted to the point of shedding blood in your striving against sin;
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
For whom the Lord loves He disciplines,
And He punishes every son whom He accepts.”
speaker: Narrator

text: It is for discipline that you endure; God deals with you as with sons; for what son is there whom his father does not discipline?
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you are without discipline, of which all have become partakers, then you are illegitimate children and not sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: Furthermore, we had earthly fathers to discipline us, and we respected them; shall we not much more be subject to the Father of spirits, and live?
speaker: Narrator

text: For they disciplined us for a short time as seemed best to them, but He disciplines us for our good, so that we may share His holiness.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the moment, all discipline seems not to be pleasant, but painful; yet to those who have been trained by it, afterward it yields the peaceful fruit of righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, strengthen the hands that are weak and the knees that are feeble,
speaker: Narrator

text: and make straight paths for your feet, so that the limb which is impaired may not be dislocated, but rather be healed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pursue peace with all people, and the holiness without which no one will see the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: See to it that no one comes short of the grace of God; that no root of bitterness springing up causes trouble, and by it many become defiled;
speaker: Narrator

text: that there be no sexually immoral or godless person like Esau, who sold his own birthright for a single meal.
speaker: Narrator

text: For you know that even afterward, when he wanted to inherit the blessing, he was rejected, for he found no place for repentance, though he sought for it with tears.
speaker: Narrator

text: For you have not come to a mountain that can be touched and to a blazing fire, and to darkness and gloom and whirlwind,
speaker: Narrator

text: and to the blast of a trumpet and the sound of words, which sound was such that those who heard begged that no further word be spoken to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: For they could not cope with the command, “If even an animal touches the mountain, it shall be stoned.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And so terrible was the sight, that Moses said, “I am terrified and trembling.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But you have come to Mount Zion and to the city of the living God, the heavenly Jerusalem, and to myriads of angels,
speaker: Narrator

text: to the general assembly and church of the firstborn who are enrolled in heaven, and to God, the Judge of all, and to the spirits of the righteous made perfect,
speaker: Narrator

text: and to Jesus, the mediator of a new covenant, and to the sprinkled blood, which speaks better than the blood of Abel.
speaker: Narrator

text: See to it that you do not refuse Him who is speaking. For if those did not escape when they refused him who warned them on earth, much less will we escape who turn away from Him who warns us from heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: And His voice shook the earth then, but now He has promised, saying, “Yet once more I will shake not only the earth, but also the heaven.”
speaker: Narrator

text: This expression, “Yet once more,” denotes the removing of those things which can be shaken, as of created things, so that those things which cannot be shaken may remain.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, since we receive a kingdom which cannot be shaken, let’s show gratitude, by which we may offer to God an acceptable service with reverence and awe;
speaker: Narrator

text: for our God is a consuming fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let love of the brothers and sisters continue.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not neglect hospitality to strangers, for by this some have entertained angels without knowing it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember the prisoners, as though in prison with them, and those who are badly treated, since you yourselves also are in the body.
speaker: Narrator

text: Marriage is to be held in honor among all, and the marriage bed is to be undefiled; for God will judge the sexually immoral and adulterers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make sure that your character is free from the love of money, being content with what you have; for He Himself has said, “I will never desert you, nor will I ever abandon you,”
speaker: Narrator

text:
so that we confidently say,
“The Lord is my helper, I will not be afraid.
What will man do to me?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember those who led you, who spoke the word of God to you; and considering the result of their way of life, imitate their faith.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus Christ is the same yesterday and today, and forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not be misled by varied and strange teachings; for it is good for the heart to be strengthened by grace, not by foods, through which those who were so occupied were not benefited.
speaker: Narrator

text: We have an altar from which those who serve the tabernacle have no right to eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the bodies of those animals whose blood is brought into the Holy Place by the high priest as an offering for sin are burned outside the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore Jesus also suffered outside the gate, that He might sanctify the people through His own blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: So then, let us go out to Him outside the camp, bearing His reproach.
speaker: Narrator

text: For here we do not have a lasting city, but we are seeking the city which is to come.
speaker: Narrator

text: Through Him then, let’s continually offer up a sacrifice of praise to God, that is, the fruit of lips praising His name.
speaker: Narrator

text: And do not neglect doing good and sharing, for with such sacrifices God is pleased.
speaker: Narrator

text: Obey your leaders and submit to them—for they keep watch over your souls as those who will give an account—so that they may do this with joy, not groaning; for this would be unhelpful for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pray for us, for we are sure that we have a good conscience, desiring to conduct ourselves honorably in all things.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I urge you all the more to do this, so that I may be restored to you more quickly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now may the God of peace, who brought up from the dead the great Shepherd of the sheep through the blood of the eternal covenant, that is, Jesus our Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: equip you in every good thing to do His will, working in us that which is pleasing in His sight, through Jesus Christ, to whom be the glory forever and ever. Amen.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I urge you, brothers and sisters, listen patiently to this word of exhortation, for I have written to you briefly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Know that our brother Timothy has been released, with whom, if he comes soon, I will see you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Greet all of your leaders and all the saints. Those from Italy greet you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Grace be with you all.
speaker: Narrator
